Award.AwardTitle: Community for Advancing Discovery Research in Education 2 (CADRE 2)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will continue and enhance the resource center (titled the Community for Advancing Discovery Research in Education, or CADRE) for the Discovery Research K-12 program. The project builds on the experience and expertise that evolved over six years in the development and implementation of CADRE. With this award, CADRE2 will maximize the individual and collective potential of DR K-12 awards by fostering collaboration and cross-sharing, and promoting the generation of new knowledge and products. CADRE2 will provide technical support to the awardees through communities of practice, a strong virtual presence, and an annual PI meeting; professional growth opportunities targeted particularly to early career researchers and developers; and aggressive outreach and dissemination to the DR K-12 community and beyond. CADRE2 will establish connections with other networks to leverage each other's strengths and services. The evaluation will focus on components that have promise for adaptation by future endeavors and by other networks.

This award will focus on support for early career researchers and developers, looking at interests and needs for professional growth. The network will also contribute to the knowledge base on capacity building, and provide a lens on dissemination of DR K-12 resources, materials, and tools within and external to the research and development community. The DR K-12 portfolio includes an estimated 300 projects that are driven by the field yet respond to parameters established by the National Science Foundation. Understanding the scope of the portfolio is important because collectively, the awards produce resources, models, and technologies that can influence the field. Convening the awardees in virtual and person-to-person venues, and promoting collaboration and interaction among the projects, maximizes the collective potential of the projects. With an emphasis on early career researchers and developers, CADRE2's impact extends into the building of the next generation of scholars. With an emphasis on communication and dissemination of the project findings and experiences, the knowledge related to STEM research will create a more evidence-based understanding of STEM education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
CADRE supports awardees in the DRK–12 program within the Education and Human Resources division at the National Science Foundation. DRK-12 projects enhance PreK-12 student learning and teaching of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM).

CADRE’s goals are to strengthen the capacity, advance the research, and amplify the influence of DRK–12 projects and researchers, and the DRK–12 program. To reach these goals, CADRE focused on convening a PI (principal investigators) meeting and a STEM Smart meeting, providing support to early career researchers, and disseminating information about the DRK–12 program and projects’ work and results. Select outcomes from CADRE’s 2014–16 activities include the following:

  • Helped DRK–12 researchers build and share new knowledge, best practices, and tools critical to increasing the impact and sustainability of project work by convening the 2016 DRK–12 PI Meeting: Making an Impact. Participants reported that the meeting was different and beneficial compared with other conferences and PI meetings (e.g., its structure and size promoted networking; attendees could readily connect around shared interest areas; attendees were more experienced and knowledgeable; attendees were exposed to more current and ongoing project work; there were opportunities to engage with or hear from NSF representatives; and tailored support was available for select early career researchers and developers). Evaluation of the PI meeting concluded that it was effective for promoting meaningful engagement and networking among colleagues and NSF representatives. Meeting materials are available on the CADREK12.org website.
  • Bridged research and practice, and broadened awareness and participation in research-based education improvement, and specifically, standards-based instructional materials in science. CADRE convened the 9th STEM Smart: Lessons Learned from Successful Schools meeting, one in a series of regional outreach efforts. More than 200 participants from various stakeholder groups attended. The meeting brought together a diverse community from research, practice, and policy and set the stage for future communication among attendees. More information and related resources are available at http://successfulstemeducation.org.
  • Increased early career researchers’ exposure to NSF and opportunities to network with early career peers and experienced researchers, learn about different work contexts and career tracks, and gain skills to advance their careers. Through the CADRE Fellows, a workforce development program for graduate students, and selected activities with CAREER program awardees, CADRE has increased current interactions, and the potential for future collaborations, among participating early career researchers.
  • Raised awareness about current research and supported communication and information sharing among researchers, practitioners, funders, and policy makers by disseminating information and resources through the CADREK12.org and succcessfulstemeducation.org websites, quarterly newsletters, social media, conference presentations, and webinars. A majority of participants report that they have no or few other sources of the kinds of supports and information offered through CADRE webinars and resources. Visit the CADRE topical spotlights on research in early learning, learning technologies, professional development, engineering, and more at CADREK12.org/resources.
